Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Optogenetic Analysis of Neurovascular Coupling

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Pashaie, Ramin
Proposal: 1454300

This proposal aims at establishing a novel paradigm for astrocytes, which are classically regarded as non-neuronal cells, forming only a support network for neurons. However, recent studies have provided evidence that astrocytes are involved in data processing in the cortex by regulating the neural response magnitude and duration. Furthermore, they appear to have an intermediary role in neurovascular coupling and the signaling pathways that mediate functional hyperemia are regulated by astrocytes. The PI proposes to establish a new platform technology to selectively manipulate neuronal/astrocytic activity and simultaneously record cellular/hemodynamic signals.

The PI has established track records in mentoring students and participating in outreach programs. The opportunities for training and teaching of undergraduate and graduate as well as making impact on undergraduate summer research program and K-12 outreach programs are excellent at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. The applicant has provided detailed plans for the development teaching materials and courses that he plans to develop as well as how he plans to mentor and train undergraduate and graduate students. The proposed outreach program is also well developed. The applicant provides clear plan for how he plans to evaluate each component of the proposed teaching and outreach program.

The PI will combine optogenetics for modulation of cellular activity of neurons and astrocytes with spectral-domain coherence tomography to monitor hemodynamic signals, and two-photon microscopy to observe cellular activity. Since both cellular activity and hemodynamics will be triggered by means of optogenetic modulation, their correlation permits conclusions about the roles of both, astrocytes and neurons. The optogenetic and microscopy experiments will be complemented by a novel electrophysiology platform that the PI has recently developed for optogenetic electrocorticography (ECoG) experiments. Electrophysiological recording of calcium waves will permit a comparison of astrocyte activity and neuronal activity.

This award is co-funded by the Biophotonics program in the Engineering Directorate and the Neural Systems program in the BIO Directorate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was an effort to better understand how networks of nerve cells, or neurons, in the brain communicate with networks of vessels that deliver vital metabolic substances, such as oxygen and energy packages, to cells to keep them live, healthy, and functional. Brain has an impressive regulatory system to tune the blood flow based on the needs of cells. When brain cells are processing information, their needs for metabolic substances increase and blood flow should elevate accordingly to address the demand of cells. Based on this, we have at least two main reasons to study blood flow regulatory system of the brain. The first reason is that in many brain imaging systems, used in clinics or for research, the activity of the brain is mapped by measuring parameters that are related to the flow of blood. If blood flow goes up in one part of the brain, we assume that part of the brain is activated. This information helps us understand what parts of the brain are engaged in different activities. To correctly map blood flow parameters to brain functions, we need to develop solid understanding of the coupling between the network of neurons and vessels in the brain. We also know that in many brain diseases, including Alzheimer?s, the normal operation of the blood flow regulatory system is disrupted which produces a condition that can initiate or contribute to the progression of such illnesses. Study of the blood flow regulatory mechanism and the coupling between neural and vascular networks in the brain help us better understand the dynamics of such disease.

Advent of new technologies in recent years, including optogenetics, which allows us to stimulate or activate neurons in the brain just by exposing them to light pulses, and optical coherence tomography, which helps us image vascular network of the brain and measure blood flow with light, provided new opportunities to study the blood flow regulatory mechanism of the brain. In this project, we combined these methods and developed a new experimental platform specifically suitable for this research. Development of the platform, including the software and hardware of the system, was the first task of this project. Once the system was ready and tested, we started running experiments with healthy animals. Collected data from these experiments helped us better understand how brain vascular network responds to different neural activity onsets. We transformed what we learned form these experiments to mathematical models that can predict the reaction of vessels if nearby brain cells are stimulated with almost any possible pattern. This project then opened the door for our research team to move toward the study of the blood flow regulatory system in disease conditions and specifically Alzheimer?s. The model we developed in this project now helps us see how reactions of vessels in the brain change under disease and how we can use this information for disease diagnosis. The idea now is to look at the reaction of vessels to neural stimulation and from that reaction estimate the state of the disease. This goal can be achieved even out of the brain in an accessible neural network such as retina.

This project helped our team to develop this science, train students specifically in the field of the bioengineering and neuroscience, and potentially contribute to the health of the society in future. We shared our experience and scientific gains via publishing papers that are accessible to the public, conference presentations, publishing tutorial manuscripts, and providing research opportunities for undergraduate and high school students. Three PhD students and three master students finished their research working on this project and they were supported by this funding. Eleven journal and multiple conference papers were published based on this research.
